awd_titl_txt: CSR: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Cloud Support for Latency-Sensitive Web Services
awd_abstract_narration:
For web applications, as little as hundreds of milliseconds of additional delay has been found to significantly degrade user experience and lower revenue. Cloud services are well-positioned to help application providers reduce users' latency by serving users from hundreds of locations across the world that have rich and diverse Internet connectivity to users' networks. However, due to various sources of inefficiency, web service performance in practice often falls well short of the potential that cloud-based deployments offer. For example, many users are incorrectly served from distant servers. Even when served from a nearby server, performance can be degraded due to circuitous routing or congestion. These suboptimal outcomes stem from the limited interface between applications and cloud providers to express goals and achieve outcomes, and often a mismatch in their goals.

This project pursues a multi-pronged cross-layer approach to enable cloud services to optimize the performance offered by web services they host. First, the researchers will develop a new approach for directing clients to nearby servers, combining the strengths of existing approaches in order to overcome their weaknesses. Part of this research will also include an investigation of how to jointly optimize client-to-server redirection and back-end data placement in order to satisfy end-to-end performance objectives. Second, this project will involve large-scale studies of web transport performance and anomalies in order to inform the design of low-latency transport protocols. Lastly, the researchers will design a system to allow cloud tenants to take advantage of the rich interdomain routing available to cloud providers, in order to best balance diverse performance and cost constraints. Thus, this project will synthesize various inter-dependent aspects of running a high performance web service.

The researchers will collaborate with the providers of popular cloud services to have a transformative effect on industrial practice and enable real-world impact. By developing solutions for cloud providers to deploy for all applications they host, this project will benefit application providers without them having to build and deploy these solutions themselves. Where applicable, the researchers will also deploy prototypes of their systems on the NSF-funded PEERING and CloudLab testbeds, which other researchers can use to build their own experimental applications. The researchers are committed to aiding other research efforts by publicly sharing measurements gathered as part of this project.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to design the cost-effective support that cloud services should offer for enabling geo-distributed web services to minimize latencies for their users. Towards this goal, we pursued a multi-pronged approach spanning many facets of operating a global-scale web service: the redirection of clients to data centers, the routing of Internet traffic from any data center to a client, and the design of geo-distributed storage.

Intellectual Merit: We collaborated with Google on Network Error Logging (NEL), an augmentation of HTTP clients which enables web service providers to precisely estimate how many clients are unable to access its service. We collaborated with Facebook on EdgeFabric, a system which enables performance- and capacity-aware route selection for content providers' egress traffic, in contrast to BGP's selection of routes. We collaborated with Nutanix on the design of their storage systems to optimize performance at scale without compromising data consistency. We also designed CRIC, which enables services deployed in the public cloud to achieve global consistency without relying on the underlying cloud platform to offer this capability.

Broader Impact: The work done as part of this project was disseminated to the community via publications at top-tier conferences such as SIGCOMM and NSDI, and via talks at several venues. Our work was used at Google, Facebook, and Nutanix to improve the availability and performance of their services. NEL is a proposed W3C standard which is implemented in the Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge web browsers. The work done by the two PhD students at Michigan who worked on this project directly contributed to their dissertations.  The PI developed a new undergraduate class on distributed systems at the University of Michigan, which has not only helped many Michigan students land coveted jobs in industry but also provided valuable experience in teaching and advising to the students who served as graduate student instructors for the class.
